has_phenotype.description: 1 of 24 (4.2%) of homozygotes display a remnant of the right dorsal aorta
at E18.5, 1 of 5 males displays unilateral testicular hypoplasia with absence of an epididymis and vas deferens dysgenesis
at E18.5, homozygotes show ventral curvature of the clavicles

at E11.5-E16.5, increased apoptosis is noted in aortic segments deriving from the fourth arch, overall, 33.3% of homozygotes aged E13.5 to 18.5 display structural abnormalities of the aorta or its branches
5 of 24 (20.8%) of homozygotes exhibit hypoplasia of the aortic arch and/or ascending aorta
1 of 24 (4.2%) of homozygotes show thickening of the aortic valve leaflets
overall, 62.5% (15 of 24) of homozygotes aged E13.5 to 18.5 display defects related to the region of the AV canal and the ventricular inlet segment
overall, 87.5% (21 of 24) homozygous mutant embryos aged E13.5 to 18.5 display abnormalities of the heart and great vessels
3 of 24 (12.5%) of homozygotes with tricuspid valve thickening show additional thickening of the mitral valve
dextroposition of the outflow tract results in a large-outlet VSD due to aberrant position of the outflow tract septum relative to the ventricular septum

type.label: abnormal heart ventricle outflow tract morphology

has_phenotype.description: 1 of 24 (4.2%) of homozygotes display a common arterial trunk with interruption of the aortic arch type B
1 of 24 (4.2%) of homozygotes display a hypoplastic pulmonary artery
2 of 24 (8.3%) of homozygotes show thickening of the leaflets of the pulmonary valve, with thickening of the aortic valve in one case
2 of 24 (8.3%) of homozygotes display an aberrant right subclavian artery

type.label: aberrant origin of the right subclavian artery

has_phenotype.description: 8 of 24 (33.3%) of homozygotes display thickening of tricuspid valve thickening, with additional thickening of the mitral valve in 3 cases

9 of 24 (37.5%) of homozygotes aged E13.5 to E18.5 show a perimembranous inlet VSD associated with overriding of the tricuspid orifice in 6 cases, VSD is more closely related to the aortic orifice in cases with a posterior position of the latter, in case of a deficient outflow tract septum, the VSD is committed to both arterial orifices
at E18.5, 15 of 16 homozygotes show ventricular septum defects

all mutant hearts with DORV display a bilateral muscular conus, 79.2% (19 of 24) of homozygotes exhibit a DORV with different relative positions of the arterial orifices, i.e. posterior (13 of 19), side-by-side (3 of 19), or slightly anterior (3 of 19) to the pulmonary orifice
1 of 24 (4.2%) of homozygotes with a common arterial trunk display interruption of the aortic arch type B, 2 of 24 (8.3%) of homozygotes exhibit interruption of the aortic arch
1 of 24 (4.2%) of homozygotes show thickening of the semilunar valve leaflets
at E18.5, the aortic and pulmonary orifices are both above the right ventricle, both exhibit valve leaflets that are patent
8 of 24 (33.3%) of homozygotes display AV valve thickening
at E18.5, both tricuspid and mitral valve are abnormally connected to the left ventricle
at E18.5, some homozygotes display normal myocardialization of outflow tract cushions, others exhibit absence of myocardialization, with only a small fibrous ridge below the semilunar valves
at E18.5, the mutant myocardium is hypercellular and less trabeculated

in some cases, fusion of the proximal cushions is incomplete, an extensive perimembranous inlet VSD is seen in cases in which outflow tract and AV cushions do not meet, incomplete fusion of the endocardial cushions results in a small membranous VSD
at E18.5, 1 of 24 (4.2%) of homozygotes display a large primum-type of atrial septal defect, the lower rim of atrial septum is still mesenchymal and has not fused with AV cushions
at E13.5, homozygotes exhibit a normal endocardial cushion volume, however, the normal decrease in total endocardial cushion volume observed in older (E15.5) wild-type embryos does not occur
at E15.5, the myocardium of the right ventricle appears spongier, probably due to ventricular dilatation

type.label: traceable author statement used in manual assertion

has_phenotype.description: homozygotes fail to survive beyond 2 hrs due to impaired cardiovascular function

type.label: traceable author statement used in manual assertion

has_phenotype.description: live-born homozygotes respond to mechanical stimulation but generally die within minutes with respiratory distress
two-thirds of homozygotes die shortly before or during birth and the remaining are born cyanotic

mutant valve leaflets are hyperplastic and retain a thick and cushion-like appearance, in contrast to septal hypoplasia, E18.5 homozygotes show abnormalities of AV and semilunar valve differentiation, right-sided valves (tricuspid and pulmonary) are more frequently affected than left-sided valves (mitral and aortic)
at E13.5 to E18.5, homozygotes show a variable degree of hypoplasia of tissues deriving from the outflow tract ridges and the septal parts of the AV cushions
homozygotes display various degrees of failure of normal remodeling of the primitive heart e.g. overriding tricuspid valve and DORV interfering with final phase of cardiac looping and wedging
live-born homozygotes exhibit respiratory distress

type.label: traceable author statement used in manual assertion

has_phenotype.description: postnatally, all mutant lungs exhibit dilated conducting airways
E18.5 homozygotes delivered by Cesarean section show a 12% reduction in birth weight
one-third of homozygotes that are born live exhibit congenital cyanosis
at E18.5, most homozygotes display dysmorphic calvaria
at E18.5, all homozygotes exhibit reduced frontal bones
at E18.5, all homozygotes exhibit reduced interparietal bones
at E18.5, most homozygotes display retrognathia
at E18.5, all homozygotes show a nearly complete agenesis of the occipital bone
at E18.5, all homozygotes exhibit reduced parietal bones
at E18.5, all homozygotes exhibit reduced temporal bones
postnatally, all mutant lungs display collapsed terminal and respiratory bronchioles
at E18.5, homozygotes exhibit an enlarged right ventricle
at E18.5, 4 of 16 homozygotes exhibit DILV
at E18.5, 3 of 16 homozygotes exhibit DORV
at E18.5, all homozygotes show a nearly complete agenesis of the alisphenoid bone
at E18.5, homozygotes with cleft palate (23%) show absence of the pterygoid process of the basisphenoid bone
at E18.5, all homozygotes exhibit reduced cranial ossification of the frontal, interparietal, parietal and squamosal bones
at E18.5, the masseteric ridge is more prominent and anteriorly and dorsally displaced
at E18.5, homozygotes with cleft palate (23%) show absence of the palatine shelf

no primary palate cleft or cleft lip was ever observed, at E18.5, 23% of homozygotes display an extensive anteroposterior cleft of the secondary palate, leaving the nasal septa exposed and extending into the soft palate
at E18.5, all homozygotes display enlarged fontanelles
newborn homozygotes display limb laxity, both fore- and hindlimbs are rotated and extend toward the midline
all newborn homozygotes exhibit a shortened ulna with a reduced olecranon process
all newborn homozygotes exhibit a shortened radius

typically, neural arch defects range from the 10th thoracic to the 5th caudal vertebra, mutant neural arches form but fail to fuse at the midline of the neural tube, newborn homozygotes exhibit spina bifida occulta
one-third of homozygotes exhibit wavy irregular ribs or fused ribs
at E18.5, 4 of 16 homozygotes display sternum abnormalities, including bifurcation, incomplete manubrium, and vestigial xiphoid process
at E18.5, 4 of 16 homozygotes display a vestigial xiphoid process
at E18.5, 2 of 16 homozygotes display rib fusions
at E18.5, all homozygotes display reduced corneal stroma thickness (~33% of wild-type)
at E18.5, all homozygotes contain a hypercellular infusion of vascularized melanocytes, neuronal cells, and mesenchymal cells in the posterior eye chamber
at E18.5, all homozygotes show hyperplasia of both the inner and outer neuroblastic layers of the retina
at E18.5, all male homozygotes exhibit testicular ectopia
at E18.5, 3 of 10 homozygotes show a dilated renal pelvis
at E18.5, 2 of 5 female homozygotes display uterine horn ectopia by ventral displacement relative to the kidneys
at E18.5, 1 of 5 female homozygotes shows adrenal ectopia
at E18.5, 1 of 5 homozygotes (females only) shows renal agenesis
when kidneys form in females, tubulogenesis is followed by progressive tubule dilatation
following tubulogenesis, female homozygotes show renal dysplastic changes, including renal tubule dilatation, degeneration of the tubular epithelium, proteinuria, and enlargement of the renal pelvis
at E18.5, the mutant spiral ganglion abnormally lies close to the sensory epithelium due to absence of the spiral limbus and Rosenthal's canal
a wider space between the epithelial ridge and basilar membrane is observed, at E18.5, all homozygotes show incomplete canalization of the scala vestibuli
at E14.5, an anterior chamber fails to form
in contrast, corneal epithelium morphology appears unaffected, at E14.5, no endothelium forms in cornea, limbus and trabecular meshworks
at E18.5, reduced collagenous matrix accumulation is noted in the extracellular space between stromal keratocytes, at E14.5-E18.5, the central stroma adheres to the lens capsule
at E13.5 or later, homozygotes exhibit failure of macrophage invasion into ocular tissues, suggesting impaired removal of vitreous hyaline cells
the mutant neural retina fails to laminate and undergo normal differentiation by E18.5
at E13.5-E14.5, the mutant cornea is abnormally thin
at E13.5-E14.5, the mutant cornea fails to separate from the lens
at E18.5, a huge cell mass of hyalocytes and blood cells accumulates in the vitreous
at E18.5, the mutant iris stroma is underdeveloped

pmidinfo.title: TGFbeta2 knockout mice have multiple developmental defects that are non-overlapping with other TGFbeta knockout phenotypes.
pmidinfo.abstract: The growth and differentiation factor transforming growth factor-beta2 (TGFbeta2) is thought to play important roles in multiple developmental processes. Targeted disruption of the TGFbeta2 gene was undertaken to determine its essential role in vivo. TGFbeta2-null mice exhibit perinatal mortality and a wide range of developmental defects for a single gene disruption. These include cardiac, lung, craniofacial, limb, spinal column, eye, inner ear and urogenital defects. The developmental processes most commonly involved in the affected tissues include epithelial-mesenchymal interactions, cell growth, extracellular matrix production and tissue remodeling. In addition, many affected tissues have neural crest-derived components and simulate neural crest deficiencies. There is no phenotypic overlap with TGFbeta1- and TGFbeta3-null mice indicating numerous non-compensated functions between the TGFbeta isoforms.

pmidinfo.title: Double-outlet right ventricle and overriding tricuspid valve reflect disturbances of looping, myocardialization, endocardial cushion differentiation, and apoptosis in TGF-beta(2)-knockout mice.
pmidinfo.abstract: BACKGROUND: Transforming growth factor-beta(2) (TGF-beta(2)) is a member of a family of growth factors with the potential to modify multiple processes. Mice deficient in the TGF-beta(2) gene die around birth and show a variety of defects of different organs, including the heart. METHODS AND RESULTS: We studied the hearts of TGF-beta(2)-null mouse embryos from 11.5 to 18.5 days of gestation to analyze the types of defects and determine which processes of cardiac morphogenesis are affected by the absence of TGF-beta(2). Analysis of serial sections revealed malformations of the outflow tract (typically a double-outlet right ventricle) in 87.5%. There was 1 case of common arterial trunk. Abnormal thickening of the semilunar valves was seen in 4.2%. Associated malformations of the atrioventricular (AV) canal were found in 62.5% and were composed of perimembranous inlet ventricular septal defects (37.5%), AV valve thickening (33.3%), overriding tricuspid valve (25.0%), and complete AV septal defects (4.2%). Anomalies of the aorta and its branches were seen in 33.3%. Immunohistochemical staining showed failure of myocardialization of the mesenchyme of the atrial septum and the ventricular outflow tract as well as deficient valve differentiation. Morphometry documented this to be associated with absence of the normal decrease of total endocardial cushion volume in the older stages. Apoptosis in TGF-beta(2)-knockout mice was increased, although regional distribution was normal. CONCLUSIONS: TGF-beta(2)-knockout mice exhibited characteristic cardiovascular anomalies comparable to malformations seen in the human population.

pmidinfo.title: TGFbeta2 in corneal morphogenesis during mouse embryonic development.
pmidinfo.abstract: To examine the roles of TGFbeta isoforms on corneal morphogenesis, the eyes of mice that lack TGFbetas were analyzed at different developmental stages for cell proliferation, migration and apoptosis, and for expression patterns of keratin 12, lumican, keratocan and collagen I. Among the three Tgfb(-/-) mice, only Tgfb2(-/-) mice have abnormal ocular morphogenesis characterized by thin corneal stroma, absence of corneal endothelium, fusion of cornea to lens (a Peters'-like anomaly phenotype), and accumulation of hyaline cells in vitreous. In Tgfb2(-/-) mice, fewer keratocytes were found in stroma that has a decreased accumulation of ECM; for example, lumican, keratocan and collagen I were greatly diminished. The absence of TGFbeta2 did not compromise cell proliferation, nor enhance apoptosis. The thinner stroma resulting from decreased ECM synthesis may account for the decreased cell number in the stroma of Tgfb2 null mice. Keratin 12 expression was not altered in Tgfb2(-/-) mice, implicating normal corneal type epithelial differentiation. Delayed appearance of macrophages in ocular tissues was observed in Tgfb2(-/-) mice. Malfunctioning macrophages may account for accumulation of cell mass in vitreous of Tgfb2 null mice.
